questions.question_text: What are two differences between media flow-around and media flow-through on Cisco Unified Border Element? (Choose two.)

choices.A: When using media flow-through, the call signaling and media are passed through the Cisco Unified Border Element.
choices.E: When using media flow-through, the call signaling goes through the Cisco Unified Border Element, but media is not passed through it.
choices.D: When using media flow-around, the call signaling goes through the Cisco Unified Border Element, but media is not passed through it.
choices.B: When using media flow-through, call signaling goes through the Cisco Unified Border Element, but media does not.
choices.C: When using media flow-around, both call signaling and media do not go through the Cisco Unified Border Element.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
Media Flow-Through 
Media Flow-Through is a media path mode where media and signaling packets terminate and originate on CUBE. As CUBE is an active participant of the call, this mode is recommended when connected outside an enterprise (untrusted endpoints). 
Media Flow-Around 
Media Flow-Around is a media path mode where signaling packets terminate and originate on CUBE. As media bypasses CUBE and flows directly between endpoints, this mode is recommended when connected within an enterprise (trusted endpoints). Media Flow-Around is supported for both audio and video calls.

Selected Answer: AD
A and D are correct

questions.question_text: A network engineer must convert an inbound number 12345551111 when it reaches Cisco UCM and then converts it to an internal extension 3022, so it can ring to a specific desk. Which action meets this requirement?

choices.D: Change the partition and calling search space on the DID for the specific desk.
choices.A: Create a route pattern 9.1XXXXXXXXXX and assign it to the trunk.
choices.C: Create a route group and route list and assign it to the translation pattern.
choices.B: Create translation pattern 12345551111, called party transform mask 3022.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
It should be B

choices.B: It allows single command QoS deployment.
choices.A: It provisions QoS for Layer 3 devices automatically.
choices.C: It expresses business relevance for applications.
choices.D: It configures QoS on the network.

questions.question_text: What is a benefit of Easy/QoS?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
The APIC-EM controller with the EasyQoS application running on top of it. Network operators express their business intent directly through a web-based graphical user interface (GUI). EasyQoS then translates this business intent into platform specific configurations that are provisioned via southbound Application Programming Interfaces (APIs) onto groups of network infrastructure devices (referred to as policy scopes), based upon the application-level business intent.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/solutions/CVD/Dec2017/APIC-EM-EasyQoS-DesignGuide-Dec2017.html

Selected Answer: C
Correct answer is C

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/solutions/CVD/Dec2017/APIC-EM-EasyQoS-DesignGuide-Dec2017.html

See the doc and search for "business relevance for applications"

questions.question_text: A network with IP telephony traffic uses LLDP to support information advertisement between network devices. An engineer must disable LLDP on the specific interface of a Cisco switch. Which two commands must be used on an interface configuration? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
These commands do work on an interface so B& C OK .
E is global A&D don't exist

choices.D: Wait until 3:15 a.m. on March 5 for garbage collection to remove the user from Cisco UCM. th
choices.B: Wait until 10 p.m. on March 5 when the user is automatically removed from Cisco UCM. th
choices.A: Wait until 3:15 a.m. on March 6 for garbage collection to remove the user from Cisco UCM. th
choices.C: Wait until 10 p.m. on March 4 when the user is automatically removed from Cisco UCM. th

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
The answer is correct:
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/voice_ip_comm/cucm/srnd/collab11/collab11/directry.html#pgfId-1045229

Nightly Sync: Cisco UCM is synchronized with Active Directory at 10 p.m. daily. However, the sync only disables the user in UCM; it doesn't immediately delete the user. UCM doesn't automatically remove disabled users right away.

Garbage Collection: Cisco UCM uses a process called garbage collection to fully remove objects (like deleted users) from the database. This process typically runs at 3:15 a.m. each day. So, in this case, after the nightly sync at 10 p.m. on March 4, the user will be disabled but not yet deleted. The garbage collection process at 3:15 a.m. on March 5 will then permanently remove the user from Cisco UCM.

The user ID is deleted from Active Directory at 10 a.m. on March 4.
The nightly sync at 10 p.m. on March 4 will detect the deletion.
Garbage collection will then run at 3:15 a.m. on March 5, which is the standard time for this process.

Selected Answer: A
A is correct, user must be marked 24 as inactive and than garbage collection will remove it

Selected Answer: A
User must be marked inactive for 24 hours before garbage collection will remove

Selected Answer: D
Garbage collection will run next at 3:15 am. So it should be D

comments.content:
Account has deleted at 10 AM, March 4. So, at Sync Interval 10 PM, March 4. User on UCM is marked inactive. At 3:15 AM March 5, which is choice D, Garbage Collection run and fount that account is inactive less than 24 hours (10PM March 4 to 3:15AM March 5). So, the account have not been deleted yet. Once, the Garbage collection run again on 3:15AM March 6. The account will be deleted due to inactive >24 hours.

So, the answer must be choice A.
